title: SS Wahehe (1922)
text:
Wahehe was a <a href="cargo%20ship">cargo ship</a> which was built in 1922 as Wadigo by <a href="Reiherstieg%20Schiffswerfte%20%26amp%3B%20Maschinenfabrik">Reiherstieg Schiffswerfte und Maschinenfabrik</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> for Woermann Linie AG. She was converted to a <a href="reefer%20ship">refrigerated</a> <a href="cargo%20liner">cargo liner</a> in about 1934.
At sea when <a href="Second%20World%20War">war</a> was declared in 1939, she sought refuge at <a href="Vigo">Vigo</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. "Wahehe" sailed from Vigo in February 1940 in an attempt to reach <a href="Germany">Germany</a> but was captured by the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>. She was declared a <a href="prize%20%28law%29">war prize</a> and handed over to the <a href="Ministry%20of%20War%20Transport">Ministry of War Transport</a> (MoWT), being renamed Empire Citizen. On 3 February 1941, she was <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed and sunk by .
Description.
The ship was built by Reiherstieg Schiffswerfte und Maschinenfabrik, Hamburg. She was laid down as "Wadigo" and completed in August 1922 as "Wahehe". She was named after first the <a href="Digo%20people">Digo people</a> and then the <a href="Hehe%20people">Hehe people</a>. Both are tribes in <a href="Tanganyika%20Territory">Tanganyika Territory</a>, which until 1918 was <a href="German%20East%20Africa">German East Africa</a> and with which Woermann Linie still traded.
The ship was long, with a beam of and a depth of . She had a GRT of 4,690 and a NRT of 2,686.
The ship was propelled by a <a href="quadruple%20expansion%20steam%20engine">quadruple expansion steam engine</a>, which had cylinders of , , and diameter by stroke.
History.
"Wahehe" was built for Woermann Linie AG, Hamburg. She was used on routes between Germany and <a href="Africa">Africa</a>. She was registered in Hamburg and given the <a href="code%20letters">code letters</a> RCQH. On 14 September 1922, "Wahehe" was the first German liner to call at <a href="Southampton">Southampton</a>, <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> after the end of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. On 27 November 1927, "Wahehe" collided with the pier on entering harbour at <a href="Boulogne-sur-Mer">Boulogne</a>, <a href="France">France</a> and sprang a leak. On 3 November 1930, she collided with the German trawler "Langeoog" at the mouth of the <a href="Weser">Weser</a> and sunk her with some loss of life.
In 1934 "Wahehe" was converted to a refrigerated cargo liner. Now , , her code letters were replaced with the <a href="Call%20sign%23Ships%20and%20boats">call sign</a> DHZD. "Wahehe" departed Hamburg before war was declared on 3 September 1939. She and several other German merchant ships took refuge at <a href="Vigo">Vigo</a> in Spain, which was officially <a href="Neutrality%20%28international%20relations%29">neutral</a>.
On the night of 9/10 February 1940, a night with <a href="Dark%20moon">minimum moonlight</a>, the German merchant ships , , , , "Wahehe" and left Vigo to <a href="Blockade%20runner%23World%20War%20II">try to run</a> the <a href="Blockade%20of%20Germany%20%281939%E2%80%9345%29">Allied blockade of Germany</a>. <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> and <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> patrols seized "Morea" and "Rostock" as early as 11 February but "Wahehe" managed to evade capture for 11 days.
On 21 February "Wahehe" was southeast of <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a> at and making for the <a href="Norwegian%20Sea">Norwegian Sea</a> when the cruiser and destroyers and intercepted her. The Royal Navy told "Wahehe"s crew that if they <a href="Scuttling">scuttled</a> her, no attempt would be made to rescue them. A party from "Kimberley" boarded her and she was escorted into <a href="Kirkwall">Kirkwall</a>, <a href="Orkney%20Islands">Orkney Islands</a> as a war prize. "Wahehe" was then towed to the <a href="River%20Clyde">Clyde</a>, arriving on 8 March.
"Wahehe" was passed to the MoWT and renamed "Empire Citizen". She was placed under the management of P Henderson & Co Ltd. Her port of registry was changed to <a href="London">London</a>. She was given the UK <a href="official%20number">official number</a> 167505 and call sign GLCB. Her GRT was recorded as 4,683, with a NRT of 2,736. "Empire Citizen" was a member of a number of convoys during the Second World War.
Convoy OG 33 formed at sea on 9 June 1940, bound for <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>. "Empire Citizen" was carrying general cargo and was bound for <a href="Las%20Palmas">Las Palmas</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>.
Convoy OB 279 departed <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> on 28 January 1941 and dispersed at sea on 2 February 1941. "Empire Citizen" was carrying general cargo bound for <a href="Freetown">Freetown</a>, <a href="Sierra%20Leone">Sierra Leone</a> and <a href="Rangoon">Rangoon</a>, <a href="Burma">Burma</a>. At 01:45 German time on 3 February, "Empire Citizen" was torpedoed by under the command of <a href="G%C3%BCnther%20Hessler">Günther Hessler</a> at . She settled slowly on an even keel and was abandoned by her crew and passengers. Another torpedo was fired at 02:33 following which she quickly sank by the stern. A total of 66 crew and 12 passengers were lost. The corvette rescued five crew and landed them at <a href="Londonderry%20Port">Londonderry Port</a> (Derry). Those lost on "Empire Citizen" are commemorated at the <a href="Tower%20Hill%20Memorial">Tower Hill Memorial</a>, London.
